stories.headline: Des Moines industrial park plan advances
stories.summary: Plans are underway to develop a 300-acre industrial park in southeast Des Moines, aiming to attract businesses including data centers. Minneapolis-based developer Ryan Cos. U.S. Inc. will ready the site north of the U.S. 69 and U.S. 65 interchange near Highway 5 for development. Andy Moffitt, vice president of real estate development, and Rick Peterson, deputy director of the Iowa Economic Development Authority, highlighted the park's potential as a major attraction for industrial companies.

stories.headline: Growing Concern
stories.summary: As the prospect for a bill banning eminent domain use from agricultural land in Iowa wanes during the legislative session, Greene County farmer Dan Tronchetti expresses his concern. Tronchetti, who received a notice from Summit Carbon Solutions to build its carbon capture pipeline on his family's land, worries about the long-term impact of such projects with little support from lawmakers. The issue has caused division among rural voters and raised awareness about the potential abuse of eminent domain rights.

stories.headline: Byers, president of Simpson College, unexpectedly dies
stories.summary: Jay Byers, the president of Simpson College and former CEO of the Greater Des Moines Partnership, has died unexpectedly on April 17 at the Sigler House, a campus residence. He had been president since July 2023. The cause of death is under investigation, and classes at the college are continuing.

stories.headline: Miller-Meeks raises more than $1 million as 2026 cycle kicks off
stories.summary: Iowa Republican U.S. Rep. Mariannette Miller-Meeks has raised over $1 million in the first quarter of the 2026 campaign cycle, signaling strong financial support for her re-election bid. The amount leads the fundraising pack among Iowa incumbents, as she emphasizes protecting Iowans from China and supporting women's sports and tax cuts. Miller-Meeks acknowledges the critical nature of fundraising for maintaining her seat in Congress.

stories.headline: Scenes of strain and devotion as pilgrimage begins
stories.summary: The annual Good Friday pilgrimage to El Santuario de Chimayó is underway, a significant Catholic spiritual journey. Alfredo Garcia, now buried nearby, carried a cross with names written in ink as a traditional sacrifice. The pilgrimage honors family roots and continues amidst deep emotional and spiritual devotion.

stories.headline: Pushing for resistance
stories.summary: Protesters at the University of New Mexico urged administrators to support diversity, equity, and inclusion amidst opposition to new federal directives associated with Trump’s anti-DEI stance. The protesters included undergraduate and graduate students and faculty who gathered to show their support for higher education and affirmative action policies.

stories.headline: Family reflects on young pair killed on walk 25 years ago
stories.summary: More than two decades after a double homicide of high school sweethearts in Chimayó, questions about the incident remain. The article recounts the tragic story of Jaylyne Quijano and Richard 'Ricky' Martinez, who were fatally shot while making a pilgrimage in 2000. The case still haunts family and community members.

stories.headline: SFIS coach, assistant AD killed in crash
stories.summary: Longtime boys basketball coach Jason Abeyta and his brother Nathan died in a head-on collision near Abiquiú. They were members of Ohkay Owingeh and were fishing at the time of the incident. The Rio Arriba County Sheriff's Office confirmed the crash and New Mexico State Police responded.

stories.headline: KC lawyer, St. Louis firm to pay $18M to hotel developers
stories.summary: A lawsuit involving developers of a 13-story Hyatt House hotel in downtown Kansas City concludes with a $18 million payment by a Kansas City lawyer and a St. Louis law firm. The property had been abandoned and in poor condition for years, with legal disputes culminating in this settlement related to the construction loan.

stories.headline: Neighbors blame officials’ lax response before deadly explosion
stories.summary: In Lexington, Missouri, residents criticize the handling of a gas explosion that killed five people, including a child. The explosion followed days of neighbors reporting the smell of natural gas with insufficient action from the city. The tragedy has sparked disappointment and anger over the apparent lack of timely intervention despite multiple warnings.

stories.headline: Mystery company plans $125M investment in Overland Park
stories.summary: A company named Project Turtle, based outside Kansas, plans to invest $125 million in Overland Park by renovating and leasing 420,000 square feet on the Aspira Campus. The project includes employing 2,000 full-time workers with an average salary of $125,000. City officials and local chambers have collaborated to attract this investment, with the developer requesting a 10-year property tax rebate on the leased property.

stories.headline: Royals again consider North KC as stadium site, sources say
stories.summary: The Royals are exploring the possibility of building a new baseball stadium in North Kansas City, potentially within Clay County, as multiple sources reveal ongoing discussions. The team has been evaluating several options, including a sports complex allowed by recent legislation. The Royals have communicated with the Merriman family, who control a significant property in the area, but no final site has been chosen yet, with the process still in its early stages.

stories.headline: State regulators won’t stop DTE’s cash payment demand
stories.summary: DTE Energy continues enforcing its policy requiring cash payments for electric bills in certain cases, despite objections from state regulators and customers. The restriction affects customers with returned payments or denied credit and limits cash bill payments to 12 months. The company is maintaining the policy to manage risks and protect customers.

stories.headline: Disaster relief bill could lead to $300 million in total aid
stories.summary: A bill to allocate $75 million in state funds for disaster relief efforts in Northern Michigan and the Upper Peninsula, following recent ice storms, has advanced in the state House. This could potentially unlock up to $225 million in federal disaster relief funds. The bill aims to address funding shortages for affected communities and avert lengthy recovery efforts.

stories.headline: To Peep or not to Peep, that is the question
stories.summary: Millions of marshmallow Peeps are made daily by Just Born Quality Confections in Bethlehem, Pennsylvania. Peeps come in various colors and flavors and have become a recognizable Easter candy, though opinions on them vary. The manufacturing process, the number of Peeps made annually, and their appeal during other holiday seasons are discussed.

stories.headline: Strong Finish
stories.summary: The Detroit Red Wings defeated New Jersey for a third consecutive win, concluding their season with a late victory against the Toronto Maple Leafs. The strong finish highlights the team's successful closing streak.

stories.headline: DOGE cuts to AmeriCorps hit projects in Wisconsin
stories.summary: Volunteers associated with AmeriCorps National Civilian Community Corps in Wisconsin are facing reduced support following funding cuts influenced by policies of former President Donald Trump and Elon Musk. Groups planning to build homes, serve as camp counselors, and restore trails in northern Wisconsin this summer are among those affected, raising concerns about the future of nonprofit community projects in the region.

stories.headline: Volunteers set up ‘Night in Emerald City’ prom theme
stories.summary: Victor Matts, reflecting on missing prom as a troubled teen, helped coordinate the "Night in Emerald City" themed prom at Washington High School. He and his daughter Jennefer attended together, highlighting the event's significance for students with special needs. The prom featured coordinated outfits, popular dances, and creative choreography inspired by the Wizard of Oz, making it a memorable occasion for all attendees.

stories.headline: Magical night for special needs students
stories.summary: Washington High School in Milwaukee hosted the 22nd annual MPS District-Wide Prom for students with unique needs, themed "A Night in Emerald City." The event provided an unforgettable evening where students and their families celebrated with dancing, themed decorations inspired by the Wizard of Oz and Wicked, and heartfelt moments. Special highlights included volunteer support and a prom experience that has been a cherished tradition for 20 years, showcasing the importance of inclusion and community.

stories.headline: State GOP enacts rules for ousting officials
stories.summary: Wisconsin Republicans have established a formal process to remove GOP officials for poor behavior amid growing tensions between the state party and local Republican leaders. The new party code of conduct sets clear procedures for removing leaders at county, congressional district, and executive committee levels if they violate the party's mission. The bylaws, approved in April, aim to manage the ongoing power struggles within the GOP.

stories.headline: Chief candidate interviewed
stories.summary: Torrey Mack, the leading candidate for Decatur police chief, underwent a two-hour interview where concerns were raised by Mayor Tab Bowling about his communication with city council members. Mack confirmed discussions with council leaders, and all council members attended the interview. The City Council is in the process of interviewing candidates to find the next police chief after Todd Pinion stepped down, with council then deciding who is selected.

stories.headline: Trump admin takes aim at international students
stories.summary: The Trump administration has intensified its dispute with Harvard University by challenging the presence of international students on campus and seeking detailed visa holder records. The Department of Homeland Security has set a deadline to provide information on visa holders allegedly engaging in unauthorized activities, with potential cancellation of grants and contracts totaling $2.7 million. Critics argue that the administration’s demands harm campus diversity and target university communities, placing Harvard under federal scrutiny.

stories.headline: Court slams defiance over deportation
stories.summary: A federal appeals court strongly opposed the Trump administration's refusal to free Kilmario Abrego Garcia from an El Salvador prison and return him to the U.S., emphasizing the escalating conflict between government branches. A federal panel unanimously refused a judge's order for sworn testimony by Trump officials, underlining tensions in handling Garcia's deportation. The ruling criticized the executive branch for defying judicial authority amid an ongoing constitutional standoff.

stories.headline: Competitors gear up for soapbox derby
stories.summary: Contestants are building soapbox derby cars in preparation for the Derby Down Bank scheduled in June downtown Decatur. Casey Hughes, the promoter, emphasized the event's creative and safety aspects, with races planned for different age groups and course features including launch ramps and backburners. The event provides a fun community race experience with three courses and races planned.

stories.headline: HISD: Discipline incidents drop 20%
stories.summary: Houston ISD saw a more than 20% decline in student disciplinary incidents during the first 27 days of the 2024-25 academic year compared to the previous year. However, incidents involving possession of firearms more than doubled during the same period. The HISD Superintendent highlighted the notable drop in fights, bullying, and other behavioral issues at a recent school board meeting, while expressing concern over the rise in firearm possession reports.

stories.headline: House OKs $1B school voucher plan
stories.summary: The Texas House passed a $1 billion school voucher program aimed at providing taxpayer money for families seeking private and religious education. The 86-63 vote marks a major victory for Governor Abbott, who has invested in expanding education options beyond public schools. Democrats opposed the plan, warning it could erode the quality of public education in Texas. The measure now moves to the Senate for further consideration.

stories.headline: Jury convicts man of capital murder in 2021 bar shooting of deputy constable
stories.summary: Eddie Miller, a 22-year-old man from Richmond, Texas, was found guilty of capital murder for the 2021 shooting death of Kareem Atkins, a deputy constable at Precinct 4. The trial jury reached the verdict after a three-day proceeding in 248th District Court, sentencing Miller to life imprisonment without parole. The shooting occurred when Miller pulled an AR-style rifle and fired on officers arresting his brother at a sports bar north of Houston.

stories.headline: High court maintains birthright order hold
stories.summary: The U.S. Supreme Court upheld a lower court decision to maintain restrictions on President Donald Trump's attempt to end birthright citizenship for children born to undocumented immigrants. The court did not rule on the merits but postponed hearing arguments until May, signaling a prolonged legal battle over this issue. Appeals courts have generally blocked such efforts, maintaining the current interpretation of birthright citizenship under the 14th Amendment.

stories.headline: Relocating NASA HQ to Houston promoted
stories.summary: Texas lawmakers are supporting President Donald Trump's proposal to relocate NASA's headquarters to Houston. Advocates argue that Houston provides a central location near NASA's existing centers and the Johnson Space Center, with lower commercial space company costs living compared to Washington, DC. NASA's headquarters lease expires in August 2028, and the agency is currently searching for a new facility in the Washington area.

stories.headline: A BIG LEGAL BLOW TO GOOGLE, BIG TECH
stories.summary: A federal judge ruled that Google held an illegal monopoly over certain aspects of search and online advertising technology. This ruling could alter Google's advertising business by dismantling its dominance in multiple markets involving advertising technology and network exchanges, marking a significant legal challenge for the tech giant.

stories.headline: Trump's tariffs cast a pall over fire rebuilding efforts
stories.summary: Uncertainty over which imports will be targeted by new tariffs is complicating budgeting and purchasing decisions for home builders and developers rebuilding homes and businesses destroyed in Southern California wildfires. The tariffs on materials from China, with duties up to 145%, lead to higher costs and delays for reconstruction projects, causing concern among contractors and homeowners.

stories.headline: $22.5-million deal OKd in malicious prosecution suit
stories.summary: Six years after a jury acquitted defense attorney Frank Carson and others of murder conspiracy charges in Stanislaus County, the county agreed to settle a malicious prosecution lawsuit for $22.5 million. The case alleged that the charges were fabricated by police and prosecutors, revealing serious misconduct and its consequences.

stories.headline: A dire choice to 'self-deport'
stories.summary: With U.S. immigration enforcement intensifying under President Trump, more unauthorized immigrants like Celeste, who overstayed visas and lived under constant threat of deportation, are choosing to leave the country on their own terms rather than risk being forcibly removed with nothing. The story highlights the human impact of immigration policies and the difficult decisions faced by many immigrants.

stories.headline: Cuts to weather service worry experts
stories.summary: The Trump administration's firings at the National Weather Service are affecting local offices and may lead to staff reductions, potentially degrading weather forecasts and public safety communications. Experts warn the cuts could reduce the agency's capability to provide timely and accurate weather predictions amid ongoing climate challenges.

stories.headline: Braun signs bill to reduce state income tax
stories.summary: Indiana Governor Mike Braun signed a bill that lowers state income taxes, aiming to reduce the tax burden for Hoosiers. The legislation includes a gradual reduction in the individual income tax rate over the next several years and adjusts thresholds for revenue requirements. However, the tax revenue is expected to grow slowly due to the income tax cuts, and the bill aims to respond to unmet revenue thresholds from the past 20 years.

stories.headline: Camping ban could change Indy’s homeless response
stories.summary: Two men in their 50s, Tom Rock and Raymond Ferguson, who have been living in tents near the Interstate 65 and 70 interchange in Indianapolis, face changing conditions as city officials propose legislation to reduce the time homeless people have to vacate areas like Fountain Square. The city’s approach includes avoiding camp shutdowns during winter and encouraging social service visits, but new regulations may alter the current protections for homeless residents.

stories.headline: Indiana has $2B gap in revenue
stories.summary: Indiana lawmakers face a $2 billion shortfall in the two-year state budget amid tariff uncertainties and economic challenges. Republican Sen. Ryan Mishler highlights the impact of tariffs and federal policies on revenue projections, which reflect a return to near-normal economic activity after the COVID-19 pandemic. The budget gap will require lawmakers to make significant cuts as the legislative session deadline approaches.

stories.headline: Shelbyville is shrinking, but track program keeps growing
stories.summary: Despite demographic decline in Shelbyville, its track program continues to see growth, highlighting the community’s ongoing commitment to youth sports and athletics. The track program’s expansion stands out amid broader population decreases, suggesting a strong local enthusiasm and engagement in sporting activities.

stories.headline: 2 killed in Fla. campus shooting
stories.summary: A shooting at Florida State University resulted in two deaths and six injuries on April 17, 2025. The suspect was apprehended by campus police shortly after the incident. Authorities have not released the names of the victims but confirmed they are caring for six others connected to the event. University President Richard McCullough expressed heartbreak over the violence at the school. This tragedy highlights ongoing concerns about mass shootings nationwide, with President Donald Trump calling it a horrible incident in a statement.

stories.headline: Neighbors in ‘crazy waiting game’ after home explosion
stories.summary: Following a home explosion, neighbors are caught in a 'crazy waiting game' as investigations and recovery efforts continue. The incident disrupted the community, causing uncertainty and concern among local residents as authorities work to determine the cause and ensure safety. Details of the explosion and its impacts remain under review with ongoing updates expected.

stories.headline: Bidding farewell to the old Austin Convention Center
stories.summary: The old Austin Convention Center is being demolished to make way for a new $1.6 billion center expected to open for the 2029 spring festival season. The original facility, which opened in 1992, hosted over 6,000 events and attracted more than 10 million visitors. The new center will be larger, offering 620,000 square feet of rentable space compared to the old center's 365,000 square feet, marking a new era for Austin's event hosting capabilities.

stories.headline: House OKs school voucher bill
stories.summary: The Texas House passed a controversial school voucher bill for the first time in its lower chamber, influenced by Governor Greg Abbott with support from President Donald Trump. The bill marks a significant shift in Texas education policy, allowing for more parental choice in education through universal school vouchers. Abbott celebrated the victory as a major step forward for education in Texas after the bill was debated and voted on late into the night.

stories.headline: Nightmare’s impacts linger 30 years later
stories.summary: The 1995 Oklahoma City bombing's devastating effects continue to be felt 30 years later, with survivors like Jason Williamson reflecting on the tragedy. The attack killed 168 people, injured nearly 700, and left lasting scars on the city and its residents.

stories.headline: Stagflation, court troubles dog Trump
stories.summary: President Donald Trump faces significant political challenges as his approval ratings decline amid economic difficulties dubbed 'stagflation' and a federal judge's warning of probable cause regarding criminal contempt by his administration. The pressure mounts as the situation recalls economic troubles from the Jimmy Carter era.

stories.headline: National parks hit with staff shortages
stories.summary: National parks across the U.S. are experiencing staff shortages due to budget cuts and layoffs, causing some restrooms and visitor centers to close. Despite hiring seasonal workers, these issues may reshape visitor experiences and access to facilities this spring.

stories.headline: Cornell joins suit opposing funding cuts
stories.summary: Cornell University has joined a lawsuit with other institutions challenging the Department of Energy's proposed immediate funding cuts to indirect costs for existing research grants. The Department of Energy aims to terminate grant awards that do not conform with new policies reducing the indirect cost rate to 15%. This is the second time Cornell has sought emergency judicial intervention as the cuts threaten research progress and training of energy scientists.

stories.headline: U.S. citizens receive notices to leave country
stories.summary: Several U.S. citizens, including Robin Peterson and Julianna Larsen, received wrongful notices from the Department of Homeland Security telling them they had seven days to leave the United States. The Department of Homeland Security is investigating as some emails may have been sent to unintended recipients. One affected citizen, Pamela Rioles Saeed, is not an immigrant but a U.S. citizen and immigration lawyer.

stories.headline: Is your tax refund above or below average?
stories.summary: A study by Upgraded Points shows New York County has one of the highest average federal tax refund amounts in the U.S. Despite a rebound in the economy, the average federal tax refund held steady at a general range of $2,800-$3,000 over 15 years but dropped during COVID to $2,549. The individual income tax and IRS data indicate the average refund rose to a record $3,252 in 2022, although the proportion of returns dropped 13% from 2021 to 2022.

stories.headline: Hannaford conducts review of its dairy supply chain amid human rights complaint
stories.summary: Hannaford Supermarkets is reviewing its dairy supply chain following activist criticism alleging that some milk is sourced from farms with substandard worker and human rights conditions. The company enlisted a third-party auditor, Enact, to oversee the investigation as part of a multiyear plan initiated by its parent company GEVA. The review covers over 180 stores in the region including South Portland.

stories.headline: Protesters in Waterville demand accountability from Rep. Jared Golden
stories.summary: More than 70 people protested at a Colby College event demanding accountability from U.S. Rep. Jared Golden, representing Maine's 2nd Congressional District. Demonstrators, part of groups like ‘Blue Dogs’ and ‘The Path Forward for Democrats,’ expressed that constituents deserve more from their representative. The protest coincided with a Goldfarb Center for Public Affairs event where Golden was scheduled to speak.

stories.headline: 'Blaze Your Own Path'
stories.summary: Isabelle St. Cyr, a 24-year-old from Monson, is the first openly transgender woman to compete in the Miss Maine pageant. Growing up participating in local pageants and inspired by her sister, Isabelle aims to challenge stereotypes and represent transgender women. She views her participation as an important message against the Trump administration's stance on transgender athletes and hopes to pave the way for more transgender individuals to participate and be accepted.

stories.headline: Gov. Mills on federal lawsuit: 'I'm happy to go to court'
stories.summary: Maine's Governor Janet Mills expressed confidence that the federal government lacks legal grounds to prevent the state from funding transgender athletes. Responding to a lawsuit initiated by the Trump administration and U.S. Attorney General Pam Bondi, Mills stated she is prepared to litigate the issues concerning transgender participation in girls sports under Title IX, describing the lawsuit as a distraction from other pressing family issues.

stories.headline: PRITZKER: TRUMP'S CUTS A MATTER OF LIFE OR DEATH
stories.summary: At an event celebrating the effectiveness of anti-violence interventions in Chicago, Governor Pritzker criticized President Trump for eliminating or threatening to end such programs, warning that 'people will die' if these funding cuts proceed. The event highlighted the crucial role these initiatives play in reducing violence in the city.

stories.headline: Links Hall, a cornerstone of Chicago’s dance scene, will permanently close in June
stories.summary: Links Hall, a vital institution in Chicago's dance community, announced its permanent closure this coming June. The closure marks the end of a significant era for local artists and the cultural landscape of Chicago's dance scene.

stories.headline: 30 years after Oklahoma City attack, anti-government rage takes new destructive form
stories.summary: The article reflects on the 30th anniversary of the Oklahoma City attack, discussing how anti-government sentiments have evolved and taken new, more destructive forms in recent times. It explores the implications of rising extremism linked to these ideologies.

stories.headline: STATE SENATOR TESTIFIES HE KNEW EXEC WAS ‘TRYING TO BUY ME OFF’ BUT STILL ASKED HIM TO HIRE EX-INTERN
stories.summary: State Senator Emil Jones III testified that he was aware an executive was attempting to buy him off, yet he still asked the executive to hire his former intern. The testimony sheds light on ongoing investigations and potential ethical conflicts involving elected officials.

stories.headline: Accountants Get Their Dream: Another Movie About Accounting
stories.summary: A new film featuring a CPA protagonist, inspired by "John Wick," is gaining interest. The movie highlights the accountant’s skills and appeals to professionals in the accounting industry, blending action elements with a financial twist.

stories.headline: Countries Across the Globe Are Vowing to Buy American
stories.summary: In response to recent U.S. trade policies and reciprocal tariffs, over 70 nations are negotiating trade deals with the U.S. Many countries want to boost exports to the U.S., while Washington looks to reduce trade deficits and pressure trading partners to comply with new terms.

stories.headline: President Has Mulled Powell Fate for Months
stories.summary: President Trump has been considering President Jerome Powell's future for months, weighing firing him before the end of his term. Discussions have included potential successors and disagreements on Fed policies, with sources indicating ongoing private talks.

stories.headline: Trump Escalates Feud With Fed, Eyes Firing Chair
stories.summary: President Trump criticized Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell and hinted at possibly dismissing him, citing concerns over the Fed's policy on tariffs and the economy. Trump expressed frustration publicly and signaled he might exercise his authority to remove Powell.

stories.headline: Judge Says Google Operates Ad Monopoly
stories.summary: A federal judge ruled that Google operates a monopoly in online advertising, violating U.S. antitrust laws and harming competitors and consumers. Alphabet plans to appeal the ruling that found unfair conditioning of access to ad products and called Google's conduct exclusionary and harmful.

stories.headline: A Televangelist Finds Herself At Home in the White House
stories.summary: Paula White, a long-time friend and spiritual advisor to President Trump, blends prayer, politics, and ministry. She has established an office in the West Wing and leads faith-based initiatives while fundraising and supporting evangelical causes linked to the administration.

stories.headline: Trump is facing more troubles
stories.summary: President Donald Trump is encountering multiple difficulties including problems with federal warnings, a mounting criminal contempt issue, and political challenges. The article highlights the worsening economic situation, termed 'stagflation,' with high tariffs, inflation, and slowing growth creating a tough landscape for Trump's administration.

stories.headline: Montcalm County has 1st Mich. measles outbreak in '25
stories.summary: Michigan's Mid-Michigan District Health Department has confirmed a measles outbreak in Montcalm County, with two additional measles cases reported. The department issued an alert to local healthcare providers but has not made a public notification of the outbreak as of early afternoon. No known exposure sites have been tied to reported cases yet.

stories.headline: CADE: ENOUGH OF NBA'S 'HUMBLING'
stories.summary: Detroit Pistons guard Cade Cunningham discusses the challenges he faced on his journey to the NBA, including balancing sports, school, and impending fatherhood while overcoming fears about his future. Despite the difficulties, he reflects on the experience as rewarding and motivating, driven by his desire to provide for his family and excel in his professional basketball career.

stories.headline: Van Hollen meets with Abrego Garcia after being turned away
stories.summary: Senator Chris Van Hollen reported on social media that he tried to visit Kilmar Abrego Garcia, who had been in prison since last month, but was denied entry. Van Hollen had attempted a surprise visit to check on Garcia's condition at a military checkpoint in El Salvador. Garcia is connected to a significant criminal investigation involving MS-13 and local crimes.

stories.headline: Trump: ‘No rush’ to set trade deals
stories.summary: President Donald Trump stated he is in no rush to reach new trade deals, particularly with the European Union and Italy, despite economic challenges including a potential recession and rising interest rates. He expressed intent to negotiate with Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni but downplayed urgent progress on trade, emphasizing caution as tariffs and economic policies evolve.

stories.headline: 2 dead, 6 wounded at Florida State University
stories.summary: A shooting incident occurred on Florida State University's campus in Tallahassee, resulting in two people dead and six others wounded. Authorities say a gunman opened fire and the victims included a sheriff's deputy whose former service was appreciated. The incident has raised concerns about campus safety and is under investigation.

stories.headline: President slams Fed chair about interest rates
stories.summary: President Donald Trump criticized Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell, accusing him of not cutting interest rates aggressively enough and signaling the Fed will keep key rates unchanged until 2026. Trump and his allies want long-term rates to drop to make borrowing easier, warning that too high rates could cause inflation to accelerate and economic growth to slow. There is ongoing political pressure and debate around the Fed's policies.

stories.headline: 2 sections of consent decree fulfilled
stories.summary: A federal judge terminated two sections of the consent decree governing the Baltimore Police Department after the DOJ and city agreed on their successful completion. The decree was meant to address systemic deficiencies including excessive force and discriminatory policing. This marks a major milestone in the decade-old legal agreement between the federal government and Baltimore regarding police reforms after the death of Freddie Gray and subsequent public unrest.

stories.headline: ‘Significant errors.’ Sheriff suspends Miami-Dade school district’s bus-camera program
stories.summary: Miami-Dade County's controversial school-bus-camera ticketing program has been suspended after Sheriff Rosie Cordero-DStutz identified significant errors in the uniform traffic violations that were issued and mailed by Bus Patrol, leading to the suspension and review of the program.

stories.headline: France forced Haiti to pay for independence. 200 years later, should there be restitution?
stories.summary: Two centuries ago, France forced Haiti to pay for its independence by extorting a hefty indemnity from the newly free Haitians to compensate former slaveholders. This has had long-lasting effects on Haiti's freedom and development. European powers succeeded in forcing the new Caribbean nation to meet these demands, but there are ongoing discussions about possible restitution.

stories.headline: Miami Commissioner Joe Carollo is cleared in corruption investigation
stories.summary: Prosecutors in the Broward State Attorney's Office have cleared Miami City Commissioner Joe Carollo of criminal wrongdoing following a years-long investigation into accusations that he stalked a Little Havana businessman and threatened a former police chief. The assistant state attorney said there was insufficient evidence to prove a criminal offense related to Carollo's actions.

stories.headline: TRAGEDY AT FSU
stories.summary: A shooting at Florida State University kills 2 and wounds 6. The suspect is identified as the son of a deputy sheriff. The shooter, a 20-year-old, was shot by officers and taken into custody. The authorities have not yet provided a motive for the shooting, and the victims did not attend the school as students.

stories.headline: Antitrust decision is latest loss for Google
stories.summary: A federal court in Alexandria, Virginia ruled that Google's advertising technology unit is an illegal monopoly. This marks a significant regulatory loss for Google following prior cases, and the company is also facing antitrust pressure in the European Union. The ruling could intensify scrutiny on Google's monopoly power in digital advertising markets.

stories.headline: 2 killed, 6 injured in shooting at Florida State
stories.summary: A shooting on the Florida State University campus resulted in two deaths and six injuries. The suspect, described as the son of a deputy sheriff, reportedly had access to a firearm. Authorities identified the shooter and are investigating the incident which occurred after a college student opened fire on campus.

stories.headline: High court will review birthright citizenship
stories.summary: The Supreme Court announced it will review President Trump's attempt to limit birthright citizenship for children of undocumented immigrants and foreign visitors. This decision has sparked debate over constitutional rights and immigration policy.

stories.headline: Trump badgers Fed on rate cuts
stories.summary: President Donald Trump criticized Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell for not reducing interest rates quickly enough, accusing the Fed of being slow and threatening further actions that could pressure the central bank. His confrontation has raised concerns about political interference in monetary policy.

stories.headline: Spy agencies undercut basis for gang deportations
stories.summary: The National Intelligence Council challenged the logic behind gang member deportations, suggesting that Trump's administration misused information to justify targeting certain individuals. This could undermine the basis for harsh deportation policies on gang-related grounds.

stories.headline: Milan's 'ultra' soccer fans — fervent and mafia-influenced
stories.summary: Milan's hardcore soccer fan groups, known as 'ultras,' are not just passionate supporters but also have alleged ties to organized crime and police influence. These groups wield significant political and social power in Italy's soccer culture, often leading to violence and controversies.

stories.headline: Palms West nurse recovering from beating reaches milestone
stories.summary: A nurse at Palms West is recovering and has reached a milestone after surviving a beating. The story details the nurse's recovery journey and support from the community as she heals from the traumatic event.

stories.headline: 2 killed in shooting on Florida State campus
stories.summary: Two people were killed and six more were injured April 17 after a shooter opened fire near Florida State University's student union, authorities said at an afternoon press conference. The Florida State Police said campus police responded immediately, neutralized and apprehended the suspect, who was also injured. Authorities declined to release information on the victims. The university canceled all classes and events related to the shooting. Florida State University President Richard McCullough and Leon County Sheriff Walter A. McNeil expressed their heartbreak over the incident.

stories.headline: Grieving mothers raise candles for every life stolen
stories.summary: At the headquarters of a club she never wanted to join, Karen Brown lifted one candle in memory of her granddaughter who died in a hail of bullets in 2021. George Poole also lifted two candles for his brother and niece who were murdered in shootings five years ago. Paula Bowe, who lost her daughter Tonya Raines in 2007, Kamisha Gibson, and Oretha Menedez attended the Mothers Against Murderers association candlelight vigil in West Palm Beach on April 12 to remember those lost to violence.

stories.headline: Urgent calls told police about Boca plane crash
stories.summary: A local 911 operator was inundated with calls on the morning of April 11 as drivers witnessed a small plane spiral in the air shortly before crashing near Boca Raton Airport. Boca Raton police released the 911 call log revealing urgent and concerned calls from witnesses, including an airport official and others reporting the distressed plane, a plane that crashed, and a giant explosion. The report highlights the emergency response and details surrounding the fatal wreck.

stories.headline: Trump’s firing spree faces legal roadblock
stories.summary: President Trump’s firing spree of independent agency leaders faces a significant legal challenge as the Supreme Court considers a 90-year-old case that may prevent many such dismissals. The court is evaluating whether the president’s traditional power to fire officials can be limited or overturned, which could impact the ability to remove Trump’s appointees.

stories.headline: State bets on taxes to fill budget holes, liberal wish lists
stories.summary: Maryland plans to increase state taxes to cover budget deficits and fund liberal initiatives. The budget relies on new taxes expected to generate $1.6 billion and aims to support education and social programs, despite concerns about balancing revenue with spending. Democrats have driven much of the state's expansion of government services and fiscal plans.

stories.headline: Federal judge decides Google monopolized web ads illegally
stories.summary: A federal judge ruled that Google illegally monopolized web advertising, a decision that could reshape the competitive landscape of the digital ad market. The ruling comes after a lengthy antitrust challenge against Google for abusing its dominant position in publisher ad servers and ad exchanges, potentially impacting Google's business practices moving forward.

stories.headline: Ukraine sees pro-Russia bias in talks for ceasefire
stories.summary: The Trump administration is optimistic about securing a peace deal between Russia and Ukraine, but Ukraine remains cautious and perceives a pro-Russia bias in the negotiations. Key negotiators emphasize the importance of controlling ‘five territories’ for a lasting peace, while acknowledging complex foreign policy pressures influencing the talks.

stories.headline: Court warns Americans next in foreign prison ‘limbo’
stories.summary: A federal appeals court has issued a warning that Americans may be next to experience the uncertain and harsh conditions faced by a deported MS-13 suspect in foreign prisons. The Trump administration’s treatment of Kilmar Abrego Garcia has been described as 'shocking', raising concerns about the government’s legal and diplomatic steps regarding detention and deportation policies.

stories.headline: Nasher appoints its next director
stories.summary: The Nasher Sculpture Center has appointed Carlos Basualdo as its next director. Basualdo, who was the Philadelphia Museum of Art's chief curator, will assume the role in May, succeeding Jeremy Strick, who is retiring in June. Basualdo, a native Argentinian, first visited the Nasher in October before being selected to lead the center.

stories.headline: DISD: Safety protocol followed
stories.summary: Dallas ISD officials stated that safety protocols were properly followed during a shooting at Wilmer-Hutchins High School. Officials noted that doors were locked and secured as required, and although doors were forced open due to fire code regulations, the shooting may not have been preventable. This statement comes amid public concern and detailed investigations following the incident.

stories.headline: Family says it’s ‘under attack’
stories.summary: The mother of a teenager accused in a fatal stabbing in Frisco spoke publicly for the first time, describing harassment and death threats her family has faced. The mother, Kala Hayes, revealed the emotional toll the situation has taken on her family and expressed concern for her younger daughter. The nonprofit Next Generation Action Network and her husband Andrew Anthony have also made public statements amid the ongoing legal and public scrutiny.

stories.headline: House OKs 'school choice'
stories.summary: Texas legislators have approved a $1 billion plan allowing Texans to use state dollars for private education through a school voucher-like program. The measure is seen as a major victory for Governor Greg Abbott and supporters of school choice who advocate for more parental options in education. Despite praise from GOP members, the plan has sparked debate over education funding priorities and potential impacts on public schools.

stories.headline: The last time a college had its tax-exempt status pulled
stories.summary: Bob Jones University lost its standing due to a ban on interracial dating by its students, which was deemed racial discrimination. The case set a precedent upheld by the Supreme Court in 1983, affirming the IRS's authority to revoke tax-exempt status of institutions that practice racial discrimination.

stories.headline: PAUL REVERE RODE HERE
stories.summary: A detailed look at the historic midnight ride of Paul Revere, retracing the route he took and highlighting the many historical markers and locations commemorating this famous Revolutionary War event. The article explores the significance of the route and the ongoing cultural remembrance in towns such as Lexington, Arlington, and Medford.

stories.headline: Outside groups claim their lists guide ICE acts
stories.summary: After a pro-Israel rally shooting and subsequent calls for boycotts, the US chapter of a century-old Zionist group is under investigation for influencing deportations of foreign students by providing inaccurate lists. Authorities are examining the group's role in government actions against individuals, including students like Rümeysa Öztürk, who was detained and awaiting trial.

stories.headline: International students push against threats
stories.summary: In response to the Trump administration's warnings and potential disciplinary actions against foreign students at Harvard, many international students emphasize the need for mutual support amid fears of losing their rights and facing accusations of anti-American sentiments.

stories.headline: Weight-loss drugs to lose coverage
stories.summary: Blue Cross of Massachusetts announced it will stop covering GLP-1 medicines for weight loss that are not prescribed for diabetes, citing soaring costs. The insurer will continue to cover these drugs when prescribed for diabetes but not for obesity. The move reflects rising demand for GLP-1 drugs and aims to control financial impacts on insurers and employers.

stories.headline: Trump lashes out at Fed chair for not cutting rates
stories.summary: President Donald Trump criticized Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell for not reducing interest rates amidst economic concerns. Trump conveyed that Powell's caution could hinder progress and emphasized his push for rate cuts. The Fed maintains its independence while navigating inflation and tariff challenges, with Trump expressing frustration over their approach.

stories.headline: SPORTS: Bleday collects 3 hits as Athletics down White Sox
stories.summary: In a strong baseball performance, Bleday secured three hits leading the Athletics to a victory over the White Sox. The game highlighted Bleday's skill and momentum, contributing to the Athletics' success in the current season.

stories.headline: Movie review: Ryan Coogler’s sexy and violent vampire film ‘Sinners’ has ample bite
stories.summary: Ryan Coogler's new vampire film 'Sinners' delivers a compelling mix of sexiness and violence, earning positive critical reception for its bold storytelling and strong thematic elements. The film offers a fresh take on the vampire genre with notable direction and impactful performances.

stories.headline: KINGS SEASON ENDS IN BLOWOUT
stories.summary: Nathan Oneto, an 11-year-old fan, mourns the Sacramento Kings' loss to the Dallas Mavericks, concluding the team's NBA playoff season with a disappointing defeat at Golden 1 Center. The defeat marks the end of a two-year run with season tickets for his family and is a significant moment for the local sports community.

stories.headline: Election data says Folsom isn’t actually ‘Trump Country’
stories.summary: Contrary to popular belief, recent election data and analysis reveal that Folsom is not a stronghold for former President Donald Trump. Progressive leaders and voting data indicate a more balanced voter base with significant support for Democrats like Kamala Harris. The area's demographics and voting patterns suggest a family-friendly, moderate community with diverse political views.

stories.headline: Supreme Court to hear case on birthright citizenship order
stories.summary: The Supreme Court announced it will hear arguments concerning President Donald Trump's executive order ending birthright citizenship. The Court's decision to review this matter follows emergency applications and legal challenges questioning the order's constitutionality, with significant implications for immigration policy in the U.S.

stories.headline: A long climb to top for Mich. speaker
stories.summary: Matt Hall, a Western Michigan University graduate, faces two decades of climbing the Michigan Republican Party's ranks as the GOP takes an increasingly important role in the state Legislature. Hall's rise to Speaker marks a significant political shift with a slippery political ladder and contentious state conventions. He has advocated for a multibillion-dollar annual budget and faced criticisms for his policies and actions, including higher tax bills for Michigan corporations.

stories.headline: China threat looms amid autos' tariff turmoil
stories.summary: Isolationist U.S. auto industry executives warn that tariffs and regulatory pressures threaten American and European automakers as China expands its electric vehicle sector aggressively. Stellantis' Chairman John Elkann highlights challenges from China's growing market share and new tariffs imposed by the U.S., creating fears of losing global automotive leadership and urging focus on managing supply chain and tariff costs while addressing the dangers posed by China and the dominant electric vehicle sector.

stories.headline: Local boys' baseball bats hit it big
stories.summary: Blake McRae and other local players from Backyard Bats, including LaMantia and Ryan LaPensee, find success as their bat company gains popularity among Wayne State players and amateur baseball ranks. Their journey from local players to top big league baseball dreams highlights how Backyard Bats has adapted to a growing craze, with their bats being used at high levels including professional games.

stories.headline: Riverfront's Smith 'ashamed' over theft
stories.summary: William Smith, former CFO of Detroit Riverfront Conservancy, expresses remorse and shame after being caught embezzling at least $44.3 million meant to revitalize Detroit's industrial riverfront. Smith faces sentencing and has been under investigation for orchestrating one of the largest and most lucrative criminal schemes in Detroit's history, accused of stealing millions over a 12-year period.

stories.headline: 'Particularly harmful consequences'
stories.summary: Sahana Jayaraman reports that Phoenix police officers pointing guns at children can have damaging effects. The story highlights an incident involving a 2-year-old and his 11-year-old cousin, where officers pointed firearms at children during a dispute. Almost 50 other minors have faced similar confrontations in recent years, raising concerns about police use of firearms around kids in Phoenix.

stories.headline: Medicaid case nabs 26 people, companies
stories.summary: Fraudsters bilked Arizona's Medicaid agency of up to $2.5 billion, with at least 26 people and entities convicted or sentenced in connection with the scams. The fraud involved buying and selling patients in need of treatment, using taxpayer money to purchase expensive items. Most victims were Indigenous people, with more indictments and convictions expected. Former Medicaid medical director has stated some knew about the scams.

stories.headline: Two killed in shooting on Florida State campus
stories.summary: Two people were killed and six more injured following a shooting at Florida State University's student union. The suspect is in custody and has invoked rights not to speak. Authorities responded immediately and neutralized the shooter. The university canceled various events following the incident, which is one of many shootings reported this year.
people: Leon County Sheriff Walter A. McNeil

stories.headline: New, former local Republican chairs at odds
stories.summary: The Hamilton County Republican Party's newly elected officers passed a resolution alleging a failed transition of power from the previous party leadership, involving missing documents and contentious disputes over party leadership changes and legislative stances.

stories.headline: Thousands of children malnourished, aid groups say
stories.summary: Aid groups report severe malnutrition among children in Gaza due to Israel's blockade, citing shortages of food, fuel, medication, and other supplies. The humanitarian crisis worsens amid continued conflict, with many Palestinians displaced and the aid system near collapse.

stories.headline: School panel takes a stand against bill
stories.summary: The Hamilton County school board passed a resolution opposing a state bill that would allow Tennessee schools to deny free education to unauthorized immigrant students, emphasizing that every child deserves a chance to thrive and experience a future without limits.

stories.headline: Defiance in freeing a man is 'shocking,' court says
stories.summary: A federal appeals court criticized the Trump administration's refusal to free Kilmar Abrego Garcia from an El Salvador prison, highlighting escalating conflicts between the executive branch and judiciary over immigration and detention policies.

stories.headline: Judge blocks ICE from deporting UW student
stories.summary: A federal judge temporarily prevented the deportation of an international University of Washington student, identified as 'John Doe,' who is challenging the Department of Homeland Security's detention and deportation efforts based on international student status and visa records.

stories.headline: Ferguson: Democrats’ $12 billion tax plan ‘too risky’
stories.summary: Washington Governor Bob Ferguson criticized a four-year, $12 billion tax proposal from Democrats, calling it 'too risky' and unsustainable. He did not offer alternative plans but expressed concerns over the state's fiscal path under the plan.

stories.headline: Supreme Court to review Washington’s challenge to Trump citizenship order
stories.summary: The U.S. Supreme Court announced it will hear oral arguments on Washington State's challenge to President Trump's executive order on birthright citizenship. The order, blocked by lower courts, remains temporarily halted, and justices will consider the legality of a nationwide pause for birthright citizenship.

stories.headline: Appeals court backs judge’s decision in deportee’s case
stories.summary: The Trump administration's claim that it cannot act on deportee Kilmar Armando Abrego Garcia from El Salvador was rejected by an appeals court. The court condemned the government's executive and judicial branch inaction and supported a lower court's instruction to facilitate Garcia's return.

stories.headline: Senator meets mistakenly deported Maryland man
stories.summary: Maryland Sen. Chris Van Hollen met Kilmar Armando Abrego Garcia, a man mistakenly deported to El Salvador, and sent a photo with a message of support. Garcia was blocked from visiting prison due to immigration court orders. El Salvador's government is investigating and ensuring Garcia's well-being.

stories.headline: Boeing sets new values after ‘brutal’ employee feedback
stories.summary: Following harsh employee feedback regarding recognition and leadership, Boeing CEO Kelly Ortberg shared plans to improve company culture and employee appreciation. He emphasized motivating employees as key to positive change and acknowledged ongoing efforts to enhance the work environment.

stories.headline: City's OT spending draws alert
stories.summary: Pittsburgh City Councilwoman Erika Strassburger warns of an imminent financial crisis due to excessive overtime spending across multiple city departments, with premium payouts higher than budgeted amounts. The concern comes amidst shrinking city revenues and heightened scrutiny from the city's finance and budget committees.

stories.headline: Schumer: Investigate as federal hate crime
stories.summary: Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer has called on the Justice Department to investigate the recent arson attack at Pennsylvania Governor Josh Shapiro's residence as a federal hate crime, citing rising antisemitism in the US and expressing concern over threats to the governor and his family.

stories.headline: TRUMP'S ORDER REMAINS ON HOLD
stories.summary: The Supreme Court has agreed to hear arguments in May regarding President Donald Trump's restrictions on birthright citizenship. His executive order to end citizenship for children of illegal immigrants has been halted nationwide by district courts, with the issue now set for Supreme Court consideration.

stories.headline: Candidates clash in debate
stories.summary: Pittsburgh Mayor Ed Gainey and Allegheny County Controller Corey O'Connor engaged in a contentious 30-minute debate, trading accusations about transparency and financial management in the city's administration. The debate highlighted their differing views on handling public infrastructure bonds and city finances.

stories.headline: Idaho LGBTQ+ laws are ‘frightening,’ trans advocates say
stories.summary: Scar Rulien, a transgender Boise State University student, criticized new Idaho laws banning transgender people from using facilities matching their gender identity and from participating in sports. Rulien described these measures as frightening and harmful, highlighting ongoing challenges faced by the LGBTQ+ community in Idaho amid recent legislative actions.

stories.headline: Idaho allows over-the-counter sale of controversial drug
stories.summary: Idaho has permitted the over-the-counter sale of ivermectin, an anti-parasitic drug, amid controversy from its use during the COVID-19 pandemic. Former CEO David Pate expressed concerns about patients being misled to use ivermectin as a substitute for vaccination, causing distress among families. The move has sparked debate about the drug's safety and efficacy in treating COVID-19.

stories.headline: Idaho man acquitted on felony assault with intent to murder
stories.summary: Curtis Lee Caton, charged with three felonies including assault with intent to murder, was acquitted by a Custer County jury who accepted self-defense claims. Caton was accused of shooting a man twice after an altercation and was held at the Lemhi County Jail for a year before trial. He pleaded guilty to separate misdemeanors related to resisting or obstructing officers and faces a maximum one-year prison sentence.

stories.headline: $120 million youth sports complex could be game-changer
stories.summary: David McMenomey plans to build a large youth sports complex in Kuna, Idaho, encompassing 114 acres without generating profit. The facility will include indoor and outdoor fields for baseball, softball, lacrosse, soccer, and flag football, along with a 5,000-seat championship baseball stadium, hotels, restaurants, and a gas station. The project aims to draw regional and national tournaments, hoping to become a major hub for youth sports in the Treasure Valley.

stories.headline: As Israel Planned Iran Attack, Trump Opted for Talks Instead
stories.summary: Israel had planned to strike Iranian nuclear sites soon but President Trump delayed the military option in favor of negotiating a deal with Iran to limit its nuclear program. Trump made the decision in part due to assessments of risks from military action. The debate highlighted the delicate balance between hawkish and diplomatic approaches to Iran, with Israeli officials recently developing plans to attack if negotiations fail.

stories.headline: Pill Could Do the Job of a Weight-Loss Injection
stories.summary: A new daily pill may be as effective as weight-loss injections like Ozempic in lowering blood sugar and aiding weight loss. The drug, orforglipron, is part of a class that blocks receptors involved in obesity and diabetes. While the pill shows promising early results, it requires further testing and regulatory review before becoming widely available. Experts are optimistic about a less invasive yet effective medication for weight loss and metabolic diseases.

stories.headline: States Resist Threats to Cut Funding Over D.E.I.
stories.summary: The Trump administration is facing legal challenges and growing pushback from states that refuse to comply with demands to cut funding for diversity, equity, and inclusion (D.E.I.) programs in public schools. States such as California, New York, and Michigan have resisted removing these programs, with some refusing to sign agreements requested by the administration. These conflicts are causing escalating tensions and legal battles over education policies nationwide.

stories.headline: Trump Turns Up Pressure, But Educators Fight Back
stories.summary: The Trump administration threatened to block Harvard University from enrolling international students unless it hands over detailed records about the student body, escalating the federal government's fight against higher education policies that it views as harmful. In response, educators and states are resisting, defending student privacy and diversity programs. The administration is also facing lawsuits and pushback against demands to cut funding tied to diversity, equity, and inclusion programs in schools.

stories.headline: Trump Assails Fed Chair for Not Cutting Rates
stories.summary: President Trump sharply criticized Federal Reserve Chair Jerome H. Powell for not cutting interest rates quickly enough to support the economy, calling the Fed's termination policy not fast enough. Trump continued his attacks via social media, suggesting politics influenced Powell's decisions. The Fed chairman defended the central bank's actions amid ongoing political pressure and uncertainty about economic outlooks amid global concerns.

stories.headline: Supreme Court Set to Consider Birthright Ban
stories.summary: The Supreme Court announced on Thursday that it would hear arguments in a few weeks over President Trump's executive order ending birthright citizenship. The brief order by the justices was unsigned and vague, but it signals the court will consider the matter seriously. The court's move pauses lower court blocks on policies that restrict birthright citizenship for children of undocumented immigrants and foreign residents. The issue is part of a broader debate on immigration and citizenship laws.

stories.headline: Trump officials’ defiance over Abrego Garcia’s deportation is ‘shocking,’ appeals court says
stories.summary: The Trump administration's efforts to block the release of El Salvadoran migrant Abrego Garcia have been called 'shocking' by an appeals court. A three-judge panel from the 4th U.S. Circuit Court rejected the Trump administration's demand to remove judges who sought to facilitate his release, highlighting tensions between the executive and judicial branches.

stories.headline: Supreme Court will review Trump’s attempt to ban birthright citizenship
stories.summary: The Supreme Court announced it will review President Donald Trump's attempt to ban automatic U.S. citizenship for children born to undocumented immigrants and foreign visitors, scheduling a special court session. The Justice Department seeks to limit lower court orders supporting birthright citizenship, with ongoing nationwide litigation and arguments expected in May.

stories.headline: Gov. Dunleavy vetoes school funding boost
stories.summary: Alaska Governor Mike Dunleavy vetoed a $1,000 increase to the Base Student Allocation, a per-student funding formula, despite the Alaska Legislature's narrow approval of the bill. Dunleavy cited the state's deteriorating revenue situation and policy that views funding schools as a policy choice, emphasizing the importance of controlling classroom sizes and teacher salaries.

stories.headline: Mount Spurr eruption now less likely though still possible, scientists say
stories.summary: Scientists monitoring Mount Spurr near Anchorage report decreased earthquake activity and ground deformation, indicating a reduced likelihood of an imminent eruption, though activity remains elevated. Observations of slowed ground deformation and melt of summit snow and ice suggest the volcano's eruption risk is diminishing after weeks of heightened activity.

stories.headline: From asylum seekers to inmates: 2 Tampa Venezuelans are sent to El Salvador prison
stories.summary: Two Venezuelan men, Luis Carlos José Marcano and Frengel Reyes, who fled poverty and discrimination, were deported back to El Salvador and imprisoned. Their families and community groups are advocating for justice, highlighting that the men were branded criminals without due process. The deportations are linked to enforcement of immigration policies despite concerns about human rights and political crises in Latin America.

stories.headline: Police: 2 dead, 6 hurt in FSU shooting
stories.summary: A 20-year-old suspect, believed to be a Florida State University student and son of a Leon County sheriff's deputy, shot and killed two people and wounded six others on campus. The suspect was taken into custody. Police responded quickly to reports, and a video showed the shooter firing as people fled. Authorities are investigating the motive but note the suspect's family background in law enforcement.

stories.headline: Fla. agents say ‘be careful’ using this insurance to save
stories.summary: Florida agents are warning homeowners about the risks associated with a growing form of homeowners coverage called "dwelling/fire" insurance. While these policies are gaining popularity, especially among rental property owners, they often lack coverage for contents, water damage, loss of use, liability, and visitor injuries. Agents advise clients to carefully consider the limitations before using dwelling/fire insurance as a cost-saving strategy amid rising home insurance prices.

stories.headline: Judge says Google is a monopoly
stories.summary: A federal judge has branded Google an abusive monopoly for the second time within a year, citing the company's illegal exploitation of its online marketing technology. The ruling reaffirms previous decisions and highlights ongoing antitrust challenges as Google faces continued scrutiny over competition and innovation stifling practices.

stories.headline: Parkway latest area district to ban cellphones
stories.summary: The Parkway School District will ban most cellphone usage by students for the next school year to reduce distractions and improve students' mental health. The new policy, which passed unanimously, prohibits personal devices from arrival to dismissal except during designated times. This follows similar bans in other St. Louis-area districts addressing concerns about phone-related disruptions and mental well-being.

stories.headline: Students sign letters of intent at Ranken Technical College
stories.summary: High school seniors are committing to skilled trades and their futures by signing letters of intent to enroll at Ranken Technical College. The event highlights a growing trend as students pursue technical education in fields such as HVAC, plumbing, carpentry, and electrical work, driven by critical job shortages and changing enrollment patterns.

stories.headline: Republicans race to repeal law
stories.summary: Missouri GOP aims to repeal future minimum wage increases and new paid sick leave rules in the Republican-controlled Missouri Senate. Although Democrats seek compromise, Senate President Cindy O'Laughlin pulled the plug on talks, indicating the repeal attempt is likely to be delayed until later. The minimum wage and sick leave requirements are part of Proposition A.

stories.headline: Staffing costs push some Minn. hospitals to the financial brink
stories.summary: Minnesota hospitals face financial distress due to the COVID-19 pandemic's impact, with 31 hospitals losing money for three or more years. Many hospitals are cutting government aid and spending cuts to sustain operations. Import tariffs may increase healthcare costs further, impacting hospitals' financial health. The state-proposed Medicare Advantage program cutting Medicaid benefits could add to this strain. Leaders are studying the impact of post-pandemic operational and financial challenges on hospital stability.

stories.headline: UnitedHealth stock price plummets
stories.summary: UnitedHealth Group's stock dropped 22% on Thursday, erasing more than $120 billion in value, after the company announced earnings outlook for the year due to a surprising jump in medical costs and a complex mix of health care utilization issues. This resulted in the largest single-day drop in UnitedHealth's stock since the 1990s. The company announced plans to execute on these factors to address the performance, describing it as "unusual and unacceptable."

stories.headline: Strongest sign yet of life out there
stories.summary: Scientists exploring life beyond Earth have detected the strongest indication yet of extraterrestrial life, potentially a molecule in a star 120 light-years away orbiting a red dwarf star. This finding suggests a possibly abundant biomolecule in the planet’s atmosphere, continuing efforts to understand life beyond the solar system.

stories.headline: Trump’s Harvard freeze runs afoul of civil rights
stories.summary: Harvard University is poised to lose billions in federal funding because of the Trump administration's refusal to yield to demands changing admissions policies related to civil rights violations. The administration froze $2.2 billion in funding, claiming Harvard's policies violated Title VI by discriminating against certain groups. This decision was challenged as discriminatory and out of compliance with civil rights law, drawing significant criticism.

stories.headline: DNR’s new licensing app still in the works
stories.summary: Minnesota's Department of Natural Resources (DNR) is behind schedule on launching a new licensing app for anglers and outdoors licenses, missing a March deadline. The $3.5 million project, delayed due to leadership changes and technical issues with project partners, is now expected to launch before 2026. The app aims to digitize permits for hunting, skiing, and other activities, reducing reliance on paper licenses and speeding up registration processes.

stories.headline: Trump’s tariff threat for imported medicines poses political risks
stories.summary: The Trump administration has initiated an investigation into whether imports of medicines and pharmaceutical ingredients pose a threat to America's national security. This move aims to justify possible tariffs on foreign-made drugs, which could lead to higher prices and shortages of critical medicines. Experts warn the tariffs could be expensive, slow to implement, and potentially disruptive to healthcare. The inquiry might take years and adds complexity to ongoing trade policies and negotiations.

stories.headline: Trump lashes out at Fed chair for not cutting rates
stories.summary: President Donald Trump criticized Jerome Powell, chair of the Federal Reserve, accusing him of delaying interest rate cuts. Trump expressed concerns over tariffs and inflation, urging the Fed to consider more aggressive rate reductions. Powell has indicated caution, emphasizing the need for monitoring inflation and economic conditions before making further changes. The Federal Reserve's decisions are closely watched amid economic uncertainties and global market pressures.

stories.headline: Lexington mayor wants more snow plows, no new taxes
stories.summary: Lexington Mayor Linda Gorton presented her proposed $539.2 million budget to city leaders, focusing on more funds for snow plows and no tax increases. The budget includes a 2% increase from the current budget and addresses personnel expenses, street safety, and pay increases for non-union employees. The budget will be reviewed by the Lexington-Fayette Urban County Council, with a final budget expected by June 30 and taking effect July 1. Mayor Gorton emphasized the budget reflects no changes in grant funding from Washington, DC.

stories.headline: Fayette County teacher charged with DUI in crash
stories.summary: A Fayette County Public Schools special education teacher, Jaime Caldwell, was arrested after driving drunk and hitting a pedestrian. The incident occurred around 6:50 a.m. near Mercer Road, and the pedestrian was hospitalized. Police charged Caldwell with DUI and failure to render aid following field sobriety tests. Caldwell admitted to drinking prior to the crash. The school district is limiting comment due to personnel matters, and Caldwell is being held at the Fayette County Detention Center.

stories.headline: Florida St. gunman kills 2, wounds 6 with mom's former service weapon
stories.summary: A 20-year-old former Florida State University student opened fire on campus using his mother's former service weapon, killing two people and wounding at least six others. Authorities quickly responded and shot the shooter, who is now in custody. The motive remains unknown, but the weapon used belonged to his mother, a former law enforcement officer. Investigations continue as the community reacts to the tragic event.

stories.headline: Trump suggests he can remove Fed chair
stories.summary: President Donald Trump recently criticized Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell, suggesting he could be fired if he does not lower interest rates. Although Powell's term ends in 2026, Trump implied potential removal during a news conference, increasing tensions around the U.S. central bank's independence. Powell was initially nominated by Trump in 2017 and reappointed by President Joe Biden in 2022. The Federal Reserve named Anna Paulson as a new regional president amid this backdrop.

stories.headline: 'The disruption has been sweeping': DOGE cuts hit Philly arts and culture
stories.summary: Federal grants approved for cultural and arts organizations, including the Woodmere Art Museum and the Asian American Digital Archive, have been cut, leaving groups scrambling for funds. The Department of Government Efficiency unexpectedly reduced support despite prior promises, affecting many local institutions. Patricia Wilson Aden, president and CEO of the Greater Philadelphia Cultural Alliance, highlighted the wide impact on the infrastructure of cultural sectors in the city.

stories.headline: Judges: Still time to right a wrong
stories.summary: An appeals court criticized the Trump administration's stance on freeing Kilmar Abrego Garcia, a man mistakenly deported to El Salvador, calling the situation shocking. The 4th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals refused to suspend a judge’s order to interview administration officials to ensure compliance with facilitating Garcia’s return to the U.S. The court emphasized that the Trump administration's position in this case risks undermining trust in the judiciary and legal integrity.

stories.headline: Youth-led group won’t take fight to Pelosi
stories.summary: The left-leaning youth organization Leaders We Deserve is set to spend $20 million in the next year's elections focusing on challenging incumbent Democrats, but plans to avoid targeting Speaker Emerita Nancy Pelosi. Led by David Hogg, a survivor of the Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School shooting, the group aims to back progressive challengers and escalate tensions within the party while excluding Pelosi from its efforts.

stories.headline: Some gains in Muni crackdown on fare cheats
stories.summary: San Francisco's Municipal Transportation Agency is seeing some success in combating fare evasion on public transit. Data shows a 6% increase in revenue collected from fare enforcement efforts, with the agency launching an oversight program to address issues related to payment enforcement. The Muni anticipates additional funding challenges, but the crackdown on fare cheats appears to be making progress in addressing revenue losses.

stories.headline: Overdose deaths in S.F. up for 4th straight month
stories.summary: Accidental drug overdose deaths in San Francisco have risen for the fourth consecutive month, with a notable increase in fatalities in March. The number of deaths linked to synthetic opioids hit a new high, nearly doubling from the previous month. Health officials remain concerned as numbers remain alarmingly high, with no single cause pinpointed for the rise. Prevention and intervention efforts continue to be key focus areas.

stories.headline: High court maintains birthright order hold
stories.summary: The Supreme Court upheld President Donald Trump's restrictions on birthright citizenship, delaying arguments to May. The court maintained a hold on Trump's executive order that aimed to end birthright citizenship for children born in the U.S. to noncitizens. The decision follows political controversy over the policy, which critics say is unconstitutional, but the court has agreed to hear arguments next month, keeping the issue unresolved for now.

stories.headline: Valero could close refinery in Benicia
stories.summary: Valero Energy Corp. announced it may close its Bay Area facility in Benicia six months after California air quality regulators fined it for excessive pollution. The company has notified the California Energy Commission of its intent to stop refining operations at the site by the end of April 2026, due to regulatory and operational challenges that could disrupt fuel supplies. Valero employs about 400 workers at the plant, making it one of the city's largest employers, and closure could have significant economic and community impacts.
